hours_text:
# Visit McDonald Observatory

#### 

* * *

McDonald Observatory is accessible to the public Tuesday – Saturday 12-5 pm, and is closed on Sunday and Monday. **All visitors must check in at the Frank N Bash Visitor Center.** Check the [calendar](http://mcdonaldobservatory.org/calendar "calendar") for available program passes, which are subject to capacity limits. 

**Spring Break at McDonald Observatory is March 10-22. During this time, we will offer a modified program schedule to serve as many visitors as possible. See details and book your passes on our[Spring Break 2026 page](https://mcdonaldobservatory.org/visitors/programs/springbreak2026).**

* * *

The Observatory and Visitors Center are located 450 miles from Austin and are on [**Central Time**](http://www.worldtimezone.com/time-usa12.php).

Frank N. Bash Visitors Center  
3640 Dark Sky Drive  
McDonald Observatory, TX 79734  
(432) 426-3640

* * *

#### 

## Programs & Facilities

collections_text:
# Home Page

[](https://mcdonaldobservatory.org/news/releases/20260113)

# [UT Astronomer Appointed President of Organization Building World’s Most Powerful Telescope](https://mcdonaldobservatory.org/news/releases/20260113)

GMTO Corporation — the international consortium building the world’s most powerful telescope, the Giant Magellan — today announced it has appointed The University of Texas at Austin’s Daniel T. Jaffe as president. He is one of two UT astronomers recently named to key leadership positions. Taft Armandroff, director of the McDonald Observatory, was elected in November to chair the GMTO board of director.

[](https://mcdonaldobservatory.org/support/renovations)

# [Help Renovate Our Visitors Center - Gifts Being Matched!](https://mcdonaldobservatory.org/support/renovations)

As our Frank N. Bash Visitors Center enters its third decade in service, we’ve started an extensive renovation of its public spaces. You are invited to be part of this transformative project by contributing to its funding. All gifts are currently being matched by sponsors!

[](https://mcdonaldobservatory.org/news/releases/20251112)

# [Unique Shape of Star’s Explosion Revealed Just a Day After Detection](https://mcdonaldobservatory.org/news/releases/20251112)

For the first time, astronomers unveiled the shape of a star's explosion at its earliest, fleeting stage. This brief initial phase wouldn’t have been observable a day later and helps address a whole set of questions about how massi...
